author: {'steamid': '76561198064139415', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 411, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 632, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1711307035}
review:
Empfehlenswert: Ja (persÃ¶nliche Wertung: 6/10)

Errungenschaften: Nein (Ãœber Ubisoft-Launcher)

Positiv:
- Gute Story, welche sich in das Assassin's Creed Universum einfÃ¼gt
- Interessantes Setting
- SchÃ¶ne 2,5D-Gestaltung
- Grafisch simpel gehalten, aber dennoch schick

Negativ:
- Teilweise komplizierte Steuerung
- Ubisoft-Launcher kann sich nicht synchronisieren
- Sehr lineare Levelgestaltung
- 1 von 3 kurzen Teilen

Fazit:
Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India ist der zweite kurze Teil einer Trilogie, welche auch in einem Spiel zusammengefasst hÃ¤tte werden kÃ¶nnen. Die Trilogie kann zwar kostengÃ¼nstig Ã¼ber ein Bundle geholt werden, aber fÃ¼r die Bedienbarkeit wÃ¤re es besser gewesen diese als ein Spiel raus zu bringen. Das ist jedoch nur Jammern auf hohem Niveau.
Ubisoft-typisch muss hier der Ubisoft-Launcher nebenbei laufen. Leider funktioniert dieser nicht immer und zeigt die Fehlermeldung das sich die Achievements nicht mit der Cloud synchronisieren kÃ¶nnen.
Ãœber das Spiel an sich kann man nicht meckern. Es handelt sich hierbei um eine gute Story (Ã¼ber die 3 Teile hinweg), welche sich gut in das AC-Universum einfÃ¼gt. Grafisch hat das Spiel einen eigenen Stil, welcher simpel, aber dennoch schick gehalten wurde.
Die schÃ¶ne 2,5D-Gestaltung ist leider aber auch die groÃŸe SchwÃ¤che des Spiels. Die Level sind sehr linear gestaltet. Man hat zwar die Wahl aggressiv oder schleichend vorzugehen, aber die groÃŸe Freiheit wie in den Haupttiteln des Spiels genieÃŸt man hier nicht. Nicht fÃ¶rderlich ist dabei die Steuerung. Oft bin ich gestorben, weil Input nicht perfekt war oder im Zusammenhang mit einer anderen gedrÃ¼ckten Taste nicht das Ergebnis erzielte, welches ich wollte.
India ist von den 3 Teilen der schlechteste Teil. Das Setting ist jedoch am Interessantesten. Leider ist der Fokus zu sehr auf Geschicklichkeit gelegt, wodurch der Gameplay-Flow aus dem ersten Teil nicht mehr da war. Besonders zu Beginn des Spiels merkte man das. Die Kletter-Passagen in der Mitte des Spiels waren auch nicht das gelbe vom Ei.
Trotz einiger kleiner MÃ¤ngel ist dieses Spiel dennoch Empfehlenswert!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198146765596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1701044940}
review:
Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India takes you on a mesmerizing journey through the colorful streets of 19th-century India. The story is captivating, pulling you into the world of assassins and intrigue. But let's be real, those controls can be a headache, and don't even get me started on the difficulty spike at the beginning! At times i felt like smashing my keyboard across the room. Still, if you can push through the frustration, the beauty of the game and its story make it worth the struggle.

Huge downgrade from ACC China IMHO. This one is a pass for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079646296', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1705674858}
review: I don't recommend this series of assassins, the games are terribly buggy, sometimes enemies detect you when they don't even have the opportunity, or the range doesn't allow them, the character interacts with a delay, the levels are bugged and sometimes it's not even possible to advance the game. I do not recommend, wasted money.

review:
DO NOT GET THIS GAME IF YOU ARE A FAN OF THE RPG AC GAMES!
This is a fun little 2.5 side-scroller type game that focuses on stealth. It requires a lot of planning to complete many objectives and you can't engage in combat until sequence 2. This is a fun game but get it on sale if you really want it.

review: Another fun part of the Chronicles line of Assassin's Creed games. I absolutely adore the art style. The difficulty increase of this from China however, was not as enjoyable. And from what I read, Russia is even worse. This one isn't too bad, just a few pretty frustrating parts, so I can still give this one a recommendation. We will see about Russia...

author: {'steamid': '76561198058413662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1705360998}
review:
[code]Assassinâ€™s Creed Chronicles: India is a frustrating, occasionally broken game that somehow manages to be even worse than its spin-off predecessor[/code]

When I [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dreamylotus/recommended/354380/]reviewed Assassinâ€™s Creed Chronicles: China[/url], the predecessor to [i]Chronicles: India[/i], I called it â€œaggressively mediocreâ€, full of â€œmissed opportunitiesâ€ and offering â€œway too limited [gameplay] options in order to feel actually rewardingâ€. My conclusion was that thereâ€™s â€œunfortunately not much of a reason to pick Chronicles: China over any of the mainline games.â€ As such, I already went into [i]Chronicles: India[/i] with little to no expectations, only to be surprised â€“ as the game turned out to be so much worse than I already feared.

Bridging the gap between [i]Assassinâ€™s Creed Syndicate[/i] and [i]Origins[/i], the [i]Chronicles[/i] trilogy was meant to be a 2.5D spin-off series thatâ€™d showcase three different protagonists, settings and times, all of which with their own look and feel accordingly.  However, despite being called a â€œtrilogyâ€, the story connections between the games are very loose as all they share is the hunt for the same MacGuffin (a small box, initially given to Shao Jun by fan favorite Ezio Auditore da Firenze).

After being lost by Shao Jun during [i]Chronicles: China[/i], the box reappears during [i]Chronicles: India[/i] (though you can probably guess what happens to the box at the end again). The game takes place in 19th century India, during the wars between the Sikh Empire and the East India Company. [i]Chronicles: India[/i] follows protagonist, Arbaaz Mir, who (hardcore) fans of the franchise might already be familiar with, as his first appearance as a protagonist and character was a graphic novel called [i]Assassinâ€™s Creed Brahman[/i], which was released three years (2013) before the release of this game (2016).

However, just like from Shao Jun in [i]Chronicles: China[/i], donâ€™t expect much from Arbaaz Mir as the story of the game is once again short, merely told through a few cutscenes, weak and thus overall forgettable as a result. Youâ€™ll once again look for the box MacGuffin, kill a few templars along the way and escape from enemies every once in a while. Wikipedia got the entire story summarized in just [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassin%27s_Creed_Chronicles#Assassin's_Creed_Chronicles:_India]four small paragraphs[/url], so feel free to read those instead if you really need to know the little plot that there is to this game.

Aside from some new gameplay elements Iâ€™ll talk about in a minute, the biggest change between [i]Chronicles: China[/i] and [i]India[/i] would probably be the art-style. [i]Chronicles: India[/i] still features a similar low-detail appearance that make it look like the world was drawn, but as shown in the screenshots, its colors are much more vibrant. But while I was quite fond of the change initially, [i]Chronicles: India[/i] a) still features a lot of boring grey caves/ruins and b) the vibrant colors make it hard to spot enemies/obstacles at times. This is especially true when it comes to the light-yellow line of sight circles some guards have, which can be incredibly hard to spot if their surroundings are too colorful. The game also introduces tripwires, which can instantly kill your character once stepped upon. And you guessed it, while theyâ€™re painted red in order to make you aware of them, they are still barely recognizable thanks to numerous colors or even objects blocking the view of them. Itâ€™s a nice change to opt for a more colorful look in an [i]Assassinâ€™s Creed[/i] game â€“ but not if your look actually interferes with the gameplay.

Speaking of gameplay, [i]Chronicles: India[/i] somehow managed to make the already unrewarding gameplay loop from [i]Chronicles: China[/i] even worse. Stealth encounters still only feature one way to be solved, your tools are basically the same as before (all more or less doing the same thing) and the combat is as awkward as ever.

However, [i]Chronicles: India[/i] decided to include some new gameplay elements to diminish the overall experience even further â€“ the aforementioned tripwires, missions where you are not allowed to kill anyone and enemies that can instantly kill you if you walk past them. A new addition are timed missions, where you have to perform certain tasks in time or itâ€™s game over â€“ which can be incredibly frustrating due to the badly spaced checkpoints and the overall janky controls.

While the controls where already too unresponsive in [i]Chronicles: China[/i], I feel like I had to actively fight with them during [i]Chronicles: India[/i]. There are simply way too many times where protagonist Arbaaz Mir performed actions opposite of what I wanted â€“ instead of jumping from window to window for example, he sometimes decided to climb into the windows, right in front of a guard. A small flick to the thumbstick is also already enough to make him move a few meters (!), which can make precisive maneuvers difficult. This gets particularly frustrating during the few platforming-heavy â€œescapeâ€ levels that [i]Chronicles: India[/i] decided to bring back for some reason, as they feature environmental dangers that once again got very bad hitboxes. A big offender are â€œfireâ€ traps during some of the ruin levels, which can still kill you even though the â€œfireâ€ animation has already disappeared.

Lastly, as itâ€™s set during the 19th century, [i]Chronicles: India[/i] features a lot of enemies with guns (which you, of course, donâ€™t use apart from two sniping sections). This usually has the annoying side effect that, immediately after you got spotted, you might get shot at from multiple locations at once with basically no chance of evasion. As Arbaaz Mir dies after just 1-3 hits (depending on your acquired health upgrades), getting spotted sometimes leads to immediate death with no chance of fighting back.

What makes this even worse are the numerous bugs in the game, the most common one being guard shots ignoring solid obstacles and hitting Arbaaz Mir even through walls or floors. Their line of sight can also be quite wrong at times, as I got spotted even while being out of their shown vision range. Lastly, during one particular occasion, a jump between two windows somehow made my character fall through the walls, at which point he was still controllable â€“ just nowhere to be seen on the screen.

Overall, it seems like the developers learned nothing from [i]Chronicles: China[/i], with almost all additions of [i]Chronicles: India[/i] making the game experience even worse somehow. Thereâ€™s nothing to be found here apart from either frustration or boredom, making [i]Chronicles: India[/i] the rare type of game that I wouldnâ€™t even recommend to hardcore fans of the franchise. Despite its short length (~5h), [i]Chronicles: India[/i] is nothing but a huge step in the wrong direction, doubling down on mistakes that should've been avoided instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018797887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1661207850}
review:
Not that it's a bad game through and through, I simply couldn't find enough novelty to go through the same experience again.
I played the AC Chronicles: China first, and thoroughly enjoyed it. Thought it was the exact length it needed to be, and this game just feels like it's tacking on more of the same to the previous one - there was already enough, imo.

I'd say, if you're into the franchise, like strategic stealth, or even tense-ish side-scrollers, defo give this one a shot. Just, perhaps, try the initial Chronicles first to figure out, if this is what you're hoping for, if you would actually like to go for seconds.

review: Very solid stealth game, was quite difficult at times and I'm usually pretty good at being sneaky. This game felt a lot shorter than the previous installment and I think that's due to a lot of time based levels. At least a third of the levels are scored based on how quick you are instead of how thorough you are which is not my favorite because I like to take my time but it did fit the narrative and did add a lot of tension to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982049123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1701701446}
review:
Wer es nicht weiÃŸ - es gibt drei Assassins Creed "Chronicles"  Teile.

China
India
Russia

Damit wird das Gameplay in eine 2,5D Welt Ã¼bertragen. Das heiÃŸt - Schleichen, Klettern, KÃ¤mpen - wie in den Open World Spielen. Das heiÃŸt aber auch, hoch klettern wo man es gar nicht will, sich hÃ¤ngen lassen, obwohl man springen will etc. Die Mechaniken haben genau wie in den normalen Teilen ihre SchwÃ¤chen.

Ansonsten sind diese Side Scroller so aufgebaut, dass jeder Bildschirm ein neues RÃ¤tsel bringt.

Wer auf 2,5D Spiele steht hat sicherlich mit allen Teilen SpaÃŸ. Wer diesen Spieletyp nicht so gern mag, oder noch nicht kennt, der sollte erst mit einem guten der Teile beginnen. Hier mein Ranking:

- Russia
- India
- China

DIe Spiele sind meiner Meinung nach nicht gut, aber auch nicht komplett schlecht. Darum bekommt mein Favorit eine positive, die anderen eine Negative Bewertung.

Russia ist mein Favorit, weil es am abwechslungsreichsten ist und eine gute AtmosphÃ¤re schafft.

India ist am hÃ¼bschesten und hat auch viele gute Ideen, aber insgesamt hat es mich nicht so abgeholt.

China finde ich am langweiligsten mit viel zu wenig Abwechslung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198802826571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1693185518}
review:
Assassinâ€™s CreedÂ® Chronicles: India is the worst game in the franchise so far. I just completed Assassin's Creed II and thought playing a smaller game would knock a few off my game queue, but I can't recommend this game. Let's analyse why I quit so early in the review.

AC India plays like a trash mobile game with this turd dumpling simmered in diarrhoea sauce called the Ubisoft launcher. If I'm going to play a game requiring 24/7 internet access on speeds measured by seconds per ping, I'm making sure it's a good Assassin's Creed game.

The art is fine, but the game design is so alien. I play Assassin's Creed for an open world experience, not some linear 2,5D clustercluck which requires me to search up a walk through on why I can't conjure a solution to slip past three clustered guards and an annoying tiger without being detected and losing my gold rating. This is the tutorial mission, as well. This is the first mission where you will learn the basics, the feel for the game, and set the mood of how it should play like.

So what's 2,5D and why isn't it 2D or 3D? Simple, the game is a 2D game with planes, lines you can switch between in a way which seems 3D, but it's not. This makes movement simple but restricting, but more importantly limits what makes the game feel fun. I want to play Assassin's Creed to scale large, open world environments, not play a platformer with neutered experience. I'll admit, it isn't for me, but if you're a die-hard fan, you might enjoy this, for the sake of being a fan of the franchise.

I've read the reviews and knew there were timed missions as well. The poor level design, controls, story, and just about everything but the art was too much for me to even consider commitment to this game, and I'll just play Assassin's Creed III, instead.

Since I have not completed the game, I will not be giving it a score. If I come back to the game, I will update the review or edit it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198360109741', 'num_games_owned': 434, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1688673391}
review:
Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India, the sequel to Assassin's Creed Chronicles: China, unfortunately falls short of its predecessor, particularly in terms of its storyline. While the platform gameplay still integrates well with the Assassin's Creed universe, and India serves as a decent setting for the game, the overall narrative and main character lack the captivating charm of Shao Jun.

The assassin-feeling gameplay remains a strong aspect of the game, delivering a high-quality and satisfying experience, from stealthy kills to immersive stealth mechanics. However, the story and main characters fail to live up to the intrigue and depth found in the first game, at least in my opinion. The narrative lacks the same level of interest and engagement, leaving the player less invested in the events unfolding.

A nice addition is the challenge maps, which are really fun, although frustrating at times.

For achievement hunters: similar to its predecessor, Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India offers 18 achievements to earn, yet disappointingly, they are not implemented on Steam. This absence is disheartening for completionists aiming to showcase their progress to others. As with the previous game, achievements are only visible for you on Ubisoft Connect, but not accessible to other players. One can see my achievements progression only on [url=https://www.backloggery.com/games.php?user=ciocolici&search=Assassin%27s+Creed+Chronicles%3A+India&alpha=1]Backloggery[/url], and written by myself on my [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/]Steam profile[/url]. Furthermore, in-game notifications for unlocking achievements are missing, irrespective of the Ubisoft Connect overlay and notification settings.
I am planning to complete this game in the future. I will then come back and share my thoughts on the achievements.

In summary, Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India does not surpass its predecessor and struggles to deliver a compelling story and memorable main character compared to Assassin's Creed Chronicles: China. Despite this, the game's platform gameplay retains its high quality and provides a satisfying experience for fans of the franchise. If you enjoyed the gameplay of the first installment and are looking for another Assassin's Creed adventure, it is worth giving Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India a try, though with tempered expectations for its storytelling aspects.

review:
Jogo divertido, simples e curto. Eu baixei e platinei no mesmo dia, igual ao ACC China.
(Eu tenho o ACC China na plataforma da Ubisoft, porque ganhei de graÃ§a.)

Apresenta maior variedade de inimigos e algumas mecÃ¢nicas novas, como nocautear inimigos, facilitando muito a conquista de completar o jogo sem matar ninguÃ©m.

Ã‰ um bom jogo, porÃ©m fiquei com a sensaÃ§Ã£o de seu antecessor ser mais divertido e nÃ£o sei bem o por quÃª. Talvez porque eu preferi a temÃ¡tica e level design do China ou pelo fato de eu ter jogado um seguido do outro, o que acaba gerando uma repetiÃ§Ã£o muito grande.

Em geral eu recomendo o jogo, principalmente para jogadores casuais ou fÃ£s da franquia.
A platina, assim como o China Ã© um tanto quanto repetitiva, porÃ©m eu achei seus requisitos mais fÃ¡ceis.
Definitivamente nÃ£o compre isso sem desconto e se for comprar, Ã© melhor levar os 3 juntos de uma vez ou comeÃ§ar pelo China pra ver se Ã© de seu agrado.

review: Game reminds me the original Prince of Persia! The 1989 or 2007 classic 2d platformer version. This is what the modern Prince of Persia should be! We have good graphics in 2.5D platformer. The action, moves, scenery and the bad guys are very similar to prince of persia. Even in the end of first chapter you meet a princess in the tower. Nostalgia! The game runs well on Steam Deck and joystick.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072094217', 'num_games_owned': 707, 'num_reviews': 617, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1673651881}
review:
Got the Assassin's Creed Chronicles games with the whole Assassin's Creed games bundle. Don't know what i was expecting from these games. Maybe a good and fun side scrolling game? This ain't it chief. The controls are so awful and slugish i just had to stop. 

It's kinda sad since i started playing all the Assassin's Creed games in order of release date. Guess i'm not going to count these as actual games and just think of them as mobile games ported to pc, because that's what they feel like and they do have the looks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198234871376', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1656239725}
review:
+ More comfortable & fluid to control than ACC China.
+ Graphics look more colorful & clearer than ACC China.
- Some of the paths & traps are harder to see because of the camera perspective.
- Harder & more annoying level than ACC China.
- Some annoying bugs where I can't climb the glowing walls, some enemies become invincible, pickpocketing enemies sometimes make you getting spotted, can't hide on the ceiling when you're at the edge of it making the enemies spotted you easily.
- Shorter gameplay than ACC China.
- Ending is lame.
My score: 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198156421302', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1657816618}
review:
Assassin's Creed Chronicles : India,

Gameplay is a step up from the previous game, but controls are once again horrible.
Story is trash, whoever has put this monstrosity together deserves his hand to be cut off, I was facepalming here A LOT.
Also sniping? Really??
Only positives I could find here are visuals and audio. 

3/10

+ Scenery, graphics, sounds and soundtracks

- Horrible story, very bad characters, stupid conversations
- Bugs
- Ending was... something else, if you like AC franchise, just avoid this stupidity

Die Missionen bieten wesentlich mehr Abwechslung und zum GlÃ¼ck wurde der Schwierigkeitsgrad ein wenig angehoben, da fÃ¼r einen guten Run nun nicht-tÃ¶dliche Vorgehensweise Pflicht sind. review: Chronicles are the only good Assassin's Creed games to me. This opinion is entirely on subjective factors so I can only recommend this game to people who are looking for the very specific experience that this trilogy offers.  If you think most Assassin's Creed games are excessively long, expensive, and boring (like I do), then this is the game for you. If you love most Assassin's Creed games, then play those games instead.

review: Just like China, India plays very well on the Deck, while most of the gameplay is the same, the art style in each title is pretty unique to its setting, making it feel a bit fresh. This one centers a bit more into the AC lore and puts a light cliffhanger that will likely be resolved in Chronicles Russia.

review:
While I do think Chronicles India has is worth playing if bought on a discount, beware of two important things.
The gameplay can make or break your experience. If you don't like timed missions or abilities being locked behind your score in levels, this one is clearly not for you. 

Everything else I found to be decent. Nothing bad overall. 
This game is just a 3-4 hour game that you play in one or two sittings.

review:
DeuxiÃ¨me Assassin's Creed Chronicles, en Inde, comme son nom l'indique. 
L'aspect visuel du jeu a Ã©tÃ© encore une fois soignÃ© aux couleurs du pays de Gandhi qui tranchent grandement avec l'ambiance parchemin/encre de chine du Chronicles Chinois. 
Sans surprise, nous retrouvons une nouvelle fois le mÃªme grand dÃ©faut du premier, Ã  savoir les commandes peu intuitives qui ne pourront pas Ãªtre changÃ©es. On peut noter aussi plusieurs passages du jeu oÃ¹ il faudra rÃ©agir Â«Ã  la secondeÂ», qui deviendront bien plus difficiles qu'ils ne paraissent Ã  cause de ces fameuses commandes. 
La difficultÃ© du jeu d'ailleurs, parlons-en.  Plus compliquÃ© et complet que son prÃ©dÃ©cesseur, la difficultÃ© a Ã©tÃ© rehaussÃ©e. Ce qui est tout Ã  fait positif. Et ce grÃ¢ce Ã  tout un tas de nouveaux Ã©lÃ©ments, de nouveaux ennemis, de nouvelles mÃ©caniques exploitÃ©es par ces derniers, ce qui donne au jeu un aspect bien plus abouti que AC Chronicles : China. 

Comptez 5 Ã  6 heures de durÃ©e de vie. Peut-Ãªtre que les diffÃ©rents dÃ©fis proposÃ©s dans le menu sauront satisfaire ceux qui dÃ©sire faire durer le plaisir un peu plus longtemps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069976975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1643432701}
review:
I love the Assassin's Creed franchise, there isn't a single one of the core games that I didn't enjoy.  This game had me ready to break a controller in the first 30 minutes, yet I charged on and pushed through.  Eventually I had to throw in the towel when I realized I was about to snap a controller after getting killed for the 10th time on the second level.  

The general controls are fine, moving around is fairly easy, but the combat is absolutely atrocious and behaves like I'm not even in control.  Enemies are seemingly placed at random without clear paths in some areas, and even navigating the levels is difficult to figure out in some places.  This is far from the core game series in every way, you're better off just watching a video playthrough on the internet and watching someone else get frustrated with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050750059', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1642857222}
review:
SEgunda  entrega de esta trilogia de este modelo de juego sacado como spinoff y ambientado en china , india , rusia .El primero ya me gustÃ³ y este tambien con un modelo muy concreto : 
Scroll lateral , maximo sigilo y una historia que contar , con mas lore para los fans de la saga y ir avanzando en diferentes misiones .
Es un buen juego bastante bueno la verdad , aunque no han tenido mucho exito me parecen tan buenos , pero en menor medida , que los juegos grandes . Con una buena historia , buen gameplay , escenarios bonitos y variados ,mucho sigilo y buenos momentos . El juego no es muy largo en 7/8 horas puedes terminarlo . 
La dificultad esta bien ajustada con partes bastante complicadas pero posibles , en resumen un buen juego que no s evendiÃ³ muy bien una lastima , pq creo que te cuentan mas en muchas menos horas que estos ultimos assassins con relleno para aburrir , una buena opciÃ³n es fresca .

author: {'steamid': '76561197963637431', 'num_games_owned': 1004, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1642092071}
review:
[h1]Assassin en fuite SIMULATOR[/h1]

AprÃ¨s avoir fait le premier Ã©pisode en Chine, j'ai enchaÃ®nÃ© sur celui-ci. En Inde cette fois... Eh bien je suis dÃ©Ã§u !

Ce que j'en retiens ?
[list][*]On Court
[*]On tue Ã  tour de bras
[*]On saute partout
[*]On on se bas [u][b]la moitiÃ© du temps[/b][/u]  contre le chrono.[/list]

J'avais apprÃ©ciÃ© le premier, avec ses faux air de [b]Mark of the Ninja[/b]. [u]On pouvait choisir de jouer la brute ou l'ombre[/u].
Pour ma part Assassin creed = Infiltration. Et c'Ã©tait bien le cas dans le premier oÃ¹ j'ai pris un malin plaisir Ã  Ã©viter les combats et Ã  ne tuer que les cibles demandÃ©es.

Ici on a bien quelques niveaux du mÃªme genre, mais c'est minoritaire.

Premier tri assez sec, la moitiÃ© des niveaux se rÃ©sument Ã  des contre-la-montre... En soit je n'ai rien contre ce genre de niveaux, mais en foutre autant ? Je veux m'infiltrer et m'amuser Ã  dÃ©nouer des situations compliquÃ©es sans me faire voir !
Pas courir comme un dÃ©ratÃ© contre un chrono en sautant dans le dos des PNJ pour les massacrer !

Autre chose que j'ai peu apprÃ©ciÃ©. Certaines situations nous forcent Ã  user des pouvoirs hÃ©lix. Toujours pour comparer avec le premier opus, c'Ã©tait peu ou pas le cas (ma mÃ©moire me fait dÃ©faut). En tous cas je me souviens trÃ¨s bien avoir terminÃ© le jeu en m'Ã©tant dit que la barre HÃ©lix ne m'avait servi Ã  rien !

On en parle aussi des phases de tir au fusil ? Elle oÃ¹ l'infiltration lÃ  ?

Et pour terminer, le pompom : La fin ?!?!? Euh lol ?
Le jeu a Ã©tÃ© coupÃ© et on doit s'imaginer nous mÃªme ce qu'il se passe ?
[spoiler]Sleeman se prend un coup de couteau, certes, mais on ne le voit pas mourir et ce n'est clairement pas explicitement dit. D'ailleurs on peut largement supposer que ce n'est pas le cas, puisque Arbaaz n'a rÃ©cupÃ©rÃ© que le diamant et pas la boite (que Sleeman a donc en sa possession ? )[/spoiler]
Vraiment j'Ã©tais estomaquÃ© de voir les pop-up m'indiquant que je pouvait faire le "new game +" puis le gÃ©nÃ©rique... alors que je m'attendais au moins Ã  un niveau final !

Bref, grosse blague ce jeu.
En soit il n'est pas mauvais, c'est un jeu de plateforme sympathique, mais clairement pas un Assassin's Creed comme on peut l'attendre. Trop d'action, pas assez d'infiltration.
Et ce foutu Chrono.... GRRRRRRRRR

author: {'steamid': '76561198156021248', 'num_games_owned': 1255, 'num_reviews': 251, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1637948533}
review:
I love Assassin's Creed and to not talk about the "Assassin's Creed Chronicles" trilogy of games would be a shame. Second in the Chronicles is Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India.

Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India isn't as great as Assassin's Creed Chronicles:China but the story and the main character makes for a great addition to the Assassin's Creed franchise. It also capitalise's on: 2.5D environments that are inspired from brush paintings (same as the first in the trilogy) and it improves on many things that AC:China needed work on. In this game you play as an assassin called "Arbaaz Mir", he was introduced in the graphic novel Assassin's Creed: Brahman and in my honest opinion it's worth a read to any Assassin's Creed fan that wants more AC. It is set in 19th-century British India in the midst of a war between "Sikh Empire and the East India Company". Again, the Templar's in this game try to take control of a "Precursor artefact" (the Koh-i-Noor diamond) and they don't manage to get it at first but...... they eventually do (i wont say anything else about the story. I've already said to much) but from here, the game takes off. 

Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India has one pet peeve that i just COULD NOT forgive it for. TIMED MISSIONS. I dont like being timed or forced to move to complete a level as fast as this game wants you to. For this one annoying reason, i sadly cannot recommend this as a "GAME" but instead i will recommend the graphic novel as it adds more to the AC franchise. It also has some tedious controls behind it. If you like Assassin's Creed: Syndicate and want to know more about the Frye twins origins then its a must read or play. 4/10 for me (Get it as a book, honestly... you'll enjoy it more) 

P.S Don't miss the secret code in this game to use in the 3rd game for a "SECRET ENDING". Code 2 out of 3. (if you buy this game that is)

author: {'steamid': '76561198918248521', 'num_games_owned': 553, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 4014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4014, 'last_played': 1628125243}
review:
Honestly, there's not a big difference between ACC China and ACC India. The gameplay is same and the only difference is story. Though I personally liked ACC China more, but this game is not bad at all.

If you liked ACC China, you'll enjoy this aswell.

If you are an Assassins Creed Fan, there's no reason why you should not have a blast playing all the AC Chronicles games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986826670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1652892086}
review:
I'm a big fan of the early titles of the series but I have also touched various others plus the very late ones and I have to say that I haven't enjoyed an AC game like this in ages (Same goes for China). I needed some time to get into the 2.5D gameplay but after 1-2 hours that is no issue anymore. What I love about this title is the colorful setting and the details that I have missed in some recent AC games (like guards speaking in their native language). The creative team did a wonderful job and what I have not seen mentioned anywhere is the music. The soundtrack is absolutely outstanding. As a musician I could instantly hear the connection between the music introduced by Jesper Kyd and the soundtrack of 'Chronicles: India.' If Ubisoft would produce triple A titles like this I believe it would bring lots of old and new people back to the franchise. The latest titles are not bad at all (though the stories could be better) but have nothing to do with AC.

TLDR: Great setting, beautiful design, better story than most AC titles, outstanding soundtrack for both 'India & China' - fans of the original titles will love it if they can accept a 2.5D setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042383071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1108, 'last_played': 1623601674}
review:
After finishing all three Chronicles games on Steam I can say Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India is probably the worst out of all of them. I unfortunately gave negative reviews to the two other games and that doesn't change here.

Similar to all the other games, the level backgrounds and getaway/escape missions are where this game really shines but we were once again hit with a bland story, boring characters, and India (for some reason) added so many insta-kill/finish parts to the game. Whether it is an escort mission where you get seen and have to restart or bombs that blend in with the background aesthetic and one-shot you, India managed to make an already frustrating spin-off series more abysmal.

Similar to my other reviews, if you love platform games and love Assassin's Creed you might enjoy this game, otherwise I would stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116939877', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1619915804}
review:
Buena continuacion de la mini saga Chronicles. Una gran mejora en lo visual se nota casi de inmediato y aplica algunas mecanicas nuevas que le dan ese punto para que no sea repetitivo como su antecesor. Verdaderamente la paleta de colores de este juego es muy notable y mucho mas colorida que su antecesor.
Una pena lo corto que es (en unas 6 horas te terminas la campaÃ±a) pero realmente es una buena experiencia. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198030985848', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1596224204}
review: The beauty of this game does not come from the story, but rather the intense and warm colours of the Indian Subcontinent. The sound is also improving upon what would be quite a stale game, story wise. If you are a fan of the series, love the region and want to experience what the region would have looked during the height of the British Empire give it a go. My advice is to wait for a sale though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198353897458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 908, 'last_played': 1613845900}
review: Another one of the jump-and-run versions of Assassin's Creed. If you are not good at jump-n-runs, you should skip this. gets sometimes quite frustrating, when you have to do the same place over and over again to continue playing - This game has NO possibility to skip missions and/or select them. For fans and people who love the story of AC, this is recommended. FOr me personally unfortunately not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043135631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2248, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1618305821}
review:
I was simply disappointed with the first game.
But I hoped that India could be a 'little' better.
So, the second game of the chronicles trilogy.
Did it disappoint me like the first game? Nope.
It really is a straight up upgrade in many ways.
The gameplay mechanics were more polished.
And overall, it simply feels like a better sequel.
But: It's just not fun, the controls are horrible.
India is actually quite tedious to play through.
So many timed missions that just aren't good.
You'll be simply forced to retry missions a lot.
It actually isn't much about stealth anymore.
This is more or less about the perfect timing.
And that just isn't Assassinâ€™s Creed anymore.
Some people might enjoy this type of thing.
But for me: It just really feels rage inducing.
The game did sometimes ignore the inputs.
I really don't like the controls in Chronicles.
And I just have to give it a negative review.
The visual style was amazing, that's a fact.
Even the story is rather enjoyable in here.
But... the gameplay simply killed it for me.
It's like 'Mark of the Ninja' but just worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996627038', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1617644948}
review: Very nice puzzle - action - stealth game. Personally i found the dificulty gap a bit overwhelming compared to Chronicles: China, but in the end it was a good overall relaxing game. The music, the artstyle, the graphics manage to capture the Assassin's Creed feeling we all love. The improoved mechanics and sometimes alternative routes in the level makes into a nice gameplay experience and story continuing what Chronicles: China started.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998447342', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1617131867}
review: After completing the AC:C games, I can easily tell this is the best game in my opinion. The game has several improvments compared to China and I loved those features such as pickpocket and the ability to roll after jumping (which is just a small detail without any effect to the gameplay). Compared to Shao Jun, Arbaaz is a much more likeable character. His story is not as tragic as Shao Jun's story therefore he has a sense of humor and joy in his tone. However, what I loved the most about this game was the colors. The color pallette truly did justice to India. The background is so immersive that you sometimes forget this is a 2.5D game. I often wondered into the scenery and stopped playing to admire the view. I can't emphasize the effect of color-palette had on my gaming experience enough. This game deserves a chance just to see the background sceneries.

author: {'steamid': '76561198317914084', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1617204480}
review:
This is the first time that I really don't like an Assassin's Creed game. Combat mechanics are better than Chronicles: China but I can't stand how annoying many aspects are. There's just too much timed missions that are so rushed. Compared to Chronicles: China, this default difficulty is pretty close to Very Hard. I understand that this kinda style needs more skill and BIG patience to do, but I can say that this is frustrating. I do really enjoyed Chronicles: China by the way.

At some level you will be forced to shoot a counterweight since it is the only way to get to the next stage but at that time I have no chakram left (chakram is something you use for shooting in this game) and the last checkpoint is just right behind the counterweight part. So how do I get those chakram? Usually it can be found on bodies. Oh there's one dead body right there but it has smoke bomb instead! There are no bodies left right there, the tower is burning, you got a few seconds left to escape, but you got no chakram just because you didn't loot enough bodies before or used all chakrams to break some lights. You pressed pause button on your controller, attempting to restart from the last checkpoint but voila your last checkpoint is where you should escape, that exact situation, where you got no chakram left. All you have to do is? Yup, restart the whole sequence.

I don't understand, maybe it was my fault for emptying my chakrams? But who knows that I will be doing the "shoot the counterweight before the tower burns you down" situation. Developers could have fixed this only with one simple step: change the loot item of the dead body from smoke bomb to chakram so we could loot them first if we got zero chakram in our pocket. We need no smoke bomb in that situation where there's only seconds left to live.

Tried hard to enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076705047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 1773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1773, 'last_played': 1613472429}
review:
AC Chronicles India certainly makes a few steps up from China, improving on the flow of gameplay and mechanics, but it is too small of a step to make it an enjoyable experience. 

In terms of gameplay this installment adds a few very useful mechanics. Now you can dash out of hiding places, roll while landing etc, to smoothen the experience. The tools are also a lot more useful and I found myself using all of them whereas in China I used only one except in the couple of situations which required another. That being said, the free running is stull sluggish and unresponsive as the problem of your character acting different than what you intended because he was close to an interactable surface remains. 

The story is worse than in China. Basically it looks like it was written by a fan of the Prince of Persia. You're the lovable rogue who has everything going for him and at the end you beat the bad guy, steal the treasure and get the girl. Literally. So you're playing somewhat of a male Mary Sue. It's almost as bad as AC Liberation and that's saying something. 

The achivements are also a bit better as there's no restriction to do the game flawlessly without laying a finger on a single enemy because, you know, you're an assassin, not just a cowardly free-runner. But even so they are not without their flaws, requiring a decent amount of grinding and some of them being incompatible with each other forcing multiple runs through the game to cmplete.

Some people have complained about the speed segments, but to me they were a step in a right direction as they did require some actual skill and livened things up. Unfortunately, the controls are still made for a race with 3 hands and 8 fingers per hand to operate properly and rebinding is still in the gutter, so the ending effect is not particularly enjoyable. 

The coding is still abysmal, thanks Ubisoft. From eagle vision's flashy effect remaining stuck, to crashes, to getting an achievement on Uplay but not getting the related award in-game (silencer/assassin costumes). etc. 

This one is definitely playable and not as frustrating as China was, so maybe give it a cautious go if you'rte a big fan of the franchise, but expect to be frustrated by missing basics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043758409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1667180601}
review:
Assassin's creed chronicles as a trilogy is one of my all-time favorite entries into the AC catalog.
Understandably shunned by most mainstream fans of the series for being so radically different yet nevertheless fully within Ubisoft's wheelhouse, the games are a departure from the open-world RPG style assassin's creed games and a return to Ubisoft's roots in the prince of Persia games.
Chronicles feature 2.5D mostly linear levels, testing the player in tight counter-combat, and stealth tactics.


Assassin's Creed Chronicles continues with India,
This entry subtly improves upon the basic mechanics in a number of ways, and on the whole is my favorite in the trilogy.
It tightens the controls and introduces some much needed additions to basic stealth and movement.
Arbaz is a better character right out of the gate, though the story is nothing exceptional here either, it is at least more engaging with a motivation we can relate to at the end.
Every part of gameplay is better emphasized in India by its sprawling and partially non-linear level design.
Several sections have you going around large vistas in any order you choose, stealthing through these sections is an incredible rush.
India has stripped out the combat option from China and now focuses fully on stealth; You can still kill enemies and enter combat but it is no longer a way to get high scores in any category.
I personally believe this change is a positive one, with the additions to stealth such as non-lethal take-downs, pick-pocketing, and ricocheting projectiles;. it feels like this game has matured in it's stealth focus and demands you to do the same.
The linear segments in India feel more confident and less like simple running levels, the worlds themselves are more vibrant and full of surprises.
The two sniper sections aren't the best but they're a neat change of pace.
As for the new tailing missions, I get finding these frustrating, I sure did my first time playing.
On replay however I've realized how easy these are once you recognize the power of your tools, I got to the first tail with a full pouch of smokebombs and ended up getting ahead of the guy.
similarly during the final segment, nothing says you can't smoke bomb your way past the searching circle.

India to me feels like a massive improvement upon China, a game I already liked plenty. It's an often demanding but highly rewarding stealth game that really speaks to me as a fan of games like thief and dishonored.
If you decide to only play on of the chronicles trilogy let it be this one.

review:
In Assassins Creed Chronicles India Ã¼bernehmen wir die Rolle eines Assassinen in Indien im 18. Jahrhundert.

Positives:

Negatives:

- die Story ist nicht besonders

Fazit:
WÃ¤hrend die Grafik den VorgÃ¤nger bei weitem Ã¼bertrifft wird der SpaÃŸfaktor eher nicht so erreicht. Gegen Ende nimmt das Spiel zwar etwas Fahrt auf, doch der GroÃŸteil des Spiels ist nicht gerade besonders. Wenn man nichts besseres zu tun hat okay, aber ansonsten nicht besonders empfehlenswert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083506805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1610924894}
review:
This came as a sequel to the ACC China, and it is amazing how it does everything worse. 

While the main character in the China episode is the best thing on it, here the main character has no personality (other than cool lover boy, as established in the tutorial, which is as cringy as it gets) and there is no distinctive features to his play style at all (if we had the athletic lead with the feet blade in China, here our lead is just...a dude.) Also, apparently India was not enough of a setting because part of the game takes place in Afghanistan (don't worry, you won't notice the difference). 

India is another place full of history that totally deserves a full open world AC game in the future. But while China left us hopeful, India left us worried of how little imagination was put into it. 

If you wanna follow the ACC episodes, you can buy it. It is not unplayable, just worse than China. But if you are trying to choose one of them to give it a try, then this should not be the one for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966870672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1608501255}
review:
Since this game is very similar to Assassin's Creed Chronicles: China, it is impossible to not compare them. I *loved* ACC: China, so I had high hopes, perhaps high expectations for this game. Not only did this game not deliver, it disappointed immensely. Now, let me begin by saying that this game might have gotten better on a second playthrough, or perhaps a third (hard mode and hard mode plus). When I played ACC: China, I nailed all three difficulties because the game was that good. In this one, I was very happy to stop playing after one playthrough. Here's my review of ACC: India.

[h1]What I (almost) liked:[/h1]
- During this game, you'll pass through several First Civilization ruins. There are traps in these, which provided a fun new addition to this game. And then, they overused them and started doing it more poorly so it completely ruined any enjoyment I would have had for this.

[i]Yes, the list of what I liked about this game is [b]this[/b] short.[/i]

[h1]What I didn't like about this game:[/h1]
- The story is completely arbitrary and doesn't even nearly seems to be at the heart of this game. It seems to just explain a backdrop for this game. [spoiler]The end state of the game is exactly what it was when the game started, thus utterly wasting your time. No one of any significance dies, no characters grow anything and at the end of the game, you have the thing you had at the start and so do the Templars. What fun.[/spoiler]
- The main character in this game is rude, overconfident, and a stereotypical action hero. If you're looking for any character development, you're not going to find it in this game. He ends the game the way he started it, learning nothing and growing nothing. He gets everything he wants done though.
- Moving away from the game's story, the mechanics are equally horrible. This game adds a multiplier since ACC: China. So where in ACC: China you felt you had a chance for choice how you wanted to do things and sometimes chose to take a fail for a slightly lesser score, now there's an absolute obligation to get a Gold score, since otherwise you'll lose your multiplier, which completely defeats your chances to get all the level objectives. And where in AC: China, I felt I wanted to get golds in Ghost or Assassin, in this game, I stopped caring after about 3 segments.
- Timed sections are executed absolutely horribly. Where in ACC: China they were kill and move fast - here you just had to deal with enemies staring at you constantly and you having to constantly wait to either kill or move past them. This is the least enjoyable way to do a timed segment and completely took the adrenaline of trying to do it fast out of it. There is one okay timed segment at the end of the game, which is a shame, since about half of this game's segments have timed elements. It almost feels as if this game has an identity crisis and can't decide if it wants to be a speed game or a stealth game. I know what I came for, and was sorely disappointed for it.
- Puckle Gun segments are completely random where sometimes, you'd hold on to a certain speed and movement pattern and would be fine, and get shot by a stray bullet the second time.
- Honestly, they seem to have taken everything that made ACC: China fun, put it away, and only put in the things that were completely unenjoyable. An absolutely tedious amount of timed segments and almost exclusively gimmicky enemies.

[h1]What I hated:[/h1]
- Now, I don't want to be petty, but I'm going to be. In a game that is literally about being an assassin that sneaks through shadows and kills and hides enemies (ignoring the 'ghost' aspect of this game for a second), having several enemies that literally cannot be killed unless you use a tool is really, really dumb. Literal trash. One of the guys that can't be killed is fairly common, as well, making me roll my eyes several times while I was [b]playing a video game[/b].
- This game has [b]way[/b] too many glitches and bugs for what it is. Examples: Enemies that ignored the tools, the character (literally so forgettable I can't remember his name now) suddenly shifts depts when jumping and jumped to his doom, sound suddenly switches off and doesn't come back until after restarting the game, poor hit box registration in several moments but most annoyingly I was killed during an escape sequence despite being very far away from the source of danger, drop and catch detection simply fails to register the button I've been holding down since the start of the drop - and then when rapidly tapping it again - and then randomly worked.

This game is not worth your time. The story is bad, the main character is annoying and forgettable, you're not missing any story, there is no reason to play this. Buy ACC: China instead. Play that, enjoy it and love it. This game will just make you wish back to when this style of game was carefully thought out.

If you are worried about missing out on story, let me summarize it in one sentence. [spoiler]You run around a whole lot, making literally no progress and ultimately get back the diamond you had at the start of the game, only to pass it on to someone else.[/spoiler]

review: This game is bad. Period. I've plaid a few stealth side scrollers that have great combat, mechanics and environment and this is not one. The story is bland and not memorable. The combat is awful and devoid of any life when it comes to an assassin creed game. It is an honest shame that they made not one not two but THREE of these turds. AC: China wasn't good either imo but this is worse.  Skip this entry of the franchise altogether stick the the main franchise that actually is fun to play as an assassin.

review:
Is it a bad game? Not really.

But it's Far too different to the regular assassin's creed experience, and its just not my genre of game.

You might enjoy it if you are keen on Stealth focused gameplay as the scoring system actively punishes combat by denying unlocks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198373978114', 'num_games_owned': 667, 'num_reviews': 377, 'playtime_forever': 2253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2158, 'last_played': 1652398102}
review:
It's so weird reading all the negative comments on here, which are undeserved. Yes, the game requires patience, timing, and skill to master, like all AC games. You probably won't be awesome the first time you play. But if you enjoyed AC China, AC India is an improvent over the first. The better you get, the more the levels flow nicely. The levels are huge, and evocative of the classic Prince of Persia game (which REALLY had infamously difficult controls).

The new protagonist has more combat options and a different set of equipment. The game takes full advantage of all the rich colors and patterns that makes the historical culture of India one of the treasures of the world.

If you are an Assassins Creed Fan, there's no reason why you should not have a blast playing all the AC Chronicles games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996273719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 798, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1605013711}
review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Assassin's CreedÂ® Chronicles: India is an Action-Adventure developed by Climax Studios.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

The successor, which begins in India in the early 19th century, remains true to itself. In other words: You can notice both the Persian prince and the other noticeable inspiration Mark of the Ninja from Klei Entertainment again and again. And like in the predecessor, the Indian assassin does not manage to clearly break away from these templates. Among other things, because both the story and the character drawing are pale again and even lag behind their predecessors. It doesn't help that in the tutorial you are on the way to your loved one like Ezio once did with the hero Arbaaz Mir. Not even that the adventure, set about 300 years after the China Chronicles, sends you back on the hunt for a magical artifact that once belonged to Ezio. Because like in China you take a hero who is anchored in the AC canon. But if you want to find out more about Arbaaz, you have to read the comic Assassin's Creed: Brahman to heart. In terms of level design and game requirements, India is also a stringent continuation of China.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ feels like Assassin's Creed even in 2D
+ good music, matching Indian language
+ very varied throughout
+ Mixture of sneak and action sequences
+ fair and yet demanding
+ Trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- AI disappointed
- Characters without depth

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Assassin's CreedÂ® Chronicles: India offers you the solid continuation of an equally solid 2D stealth platformer series. Like in China back then, only now in India.

Und wie im VorgÃ¤nger schafft es auch der indische Assassine nicht, sich deutlich von diesen Schablonen zu lÃ¶sen. Unter anderem auch, weil sowohl Geschichte als auch Charakterzeichnung wieder blass und sogar hinter dem VorgÃ¤nger zurÃ¼ckbleiben. Da hilft es auch nicht, dass man im Tutorial wie einstmals Ezio mit dem Helden Arbaaz Mir auf dem Weg zu seiner Liebsten ist. Auch nicht, dass das etwa 300 Jahre nach den China-Chroniken spielende Abenteuer einen wieder auf die Jagd nach einem magischen Aretfakt schickt, dass einst Ezio gehÃ¶rte. Denn wie in China nimmt man zwar einen Helden, der im AC-Kanon verankert ist. Doch wer mehr Ã¼ber Arbaaz erfahren mÃ¶chte, muss sich den Comic Assassinâ€™s Creed: Brahman zu GemÃ¼te fÃ¼hren. Beim Leveldesign und den Spielanforderungen zeigt sich India ebenfalls als stringente Fortsetzung zu China. 

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ fÃ¼hlt sich auch in 2D an wie Assassinâ€™s Creed 
+ gelungene Musik, passende indische Sprache
+ durchwegs sehr abwechslungsreich

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198170159766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1604790288}
review:
It breaks my heart to do this because I LOVE the entire Assassin's Creed franchise, but this is probably the only entry I don't like out of all of them. In fact, I kind of hate it. While the mechanics introduced from AC China are polished up on, and there's a nice addition of looting guards and streak killing enemies in combat, AC India fails to surpass AC China despite of its improvements.

Basically halfway through the game it forces you to do a whole lot of timed missions where it rushes you to the end and pretty much removes all the fun optional objectives present in AC China. You are rewarded for rushing rather than exploring, and I think that's an absolute shame because at a mechanical level, the controls for this game are much much smoother than AC China. On top of that, there's a lot of forced enemy kill count objectives and forced combat sections that just ruin the freedom that comes with AC games.

I would only recommend this game to those who enjoyed the fast paced action set pieces from AC China, but want nothing but those, rather than the option to be slow and deliberate or speedrun through missions. Otherwise, this game falls flat on its face by disrespecting the player's ability to choose how they want to approach the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 603, 'playtime_forever': 1279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1279, 'last_played': 1604045997}
review:
I consider Assassinâ€™s Creed Chronicles as a 3-part game instead of 3 separate titles, because they have so much in common.
Itâ€™s an Assassinâ€™s Creed spinoff, that plays in 2.5D. Itâ€™s mostly 2D with a layer system. It clearly takes inspiration from the superior Mark of the Ninja game, because Chronicles has a lot of the same systems, but not as polished.
Itâ€™s a stealth game, meaning that the game gives incentive for clearing sections without being spotted. There are various ways and tools to achieve that, and even a cheap combat system in case you get caught. You can see the enemy vision cones, allowing you to better prepare how to tackle each section. As you progress, more mechanics are gradually introduced, and I like how itâ€™s implemented, slowly increasing difficulty but also giving more options to balance.
Although you can silently kill enemies, every section can be completed by not killing anyone, which is a bit harder and will make you use all the tools at your disposal to distract enemies. That is also how you get the highest score in each section. There are also some running levels thrown in the mix, with a focus of completing them as fast as possible. Getting high scores and fast times in the running levels is also how you unlock upgrades.
Besides the obvious difference in setting (China, India and Russia), each game plays mostly the same, although India and Russia have more instant-fail moments, making them a bit harder and more frustrating than China. India and Russia also have some challenge rooms, but itâ€™s just a small bonus.
Now, are they worth it? Well, for me itâ€™s a mixed bag. I 100% completed all 3 settings, and while the visuals are pretty, allowing you to experience 3 more Assassinâ€™s Creed-style distinct settings in a short time, the gameplay falls a bit short. Itâ€™s basically a worst Mark of the Ninja, but for Assassinâ€™s Creed fans. In that regard, I can recommend a playthrough of each title if youâ€™re an Assassinâ€™s Creed fan and grab them on sale as a Trilogy. Otherwise, you can skip Chronicles, and you wonâ€™t lose much.

review:
Assassins Creed Chronicles ist ein "2,5D" Plattformer/Action-RPG/Sidescroller. Die Chronicles-Reihe ist ein dreiteiliges Spin-Off der Hauptspiele, bestehend aus China, India und Russia.
Chronicles India wurde als 2. verÃ¶ffentlicht. Alle Teile haben nichts bzw. nur sehr lose etwas mit der Story der jeweils anderen zu tun.
India hat mich leider nicht gut unterhalten. Der Artstyle ist zwar wirklich deutlich schÃ¶ner als in China, aber die Geschichte ist nicht besonders spannend und im Gameplay gab es keine bzw. zu wenig Neuerungen gegenÃ¼ber dem ersten Spiel, sodass es sich schlicht und einfach wie ein Replay von China in einer anderen Umgebung angefÃ¼hlt hat.
Wem der erste Teil gefallen hat, der wird hier sicher SpaÃŸ haben, aber ich bin weder ein groÃŸer Sidescroller-Fan, noch hat mich dieses Spiel im Gameplay besonders gut abgeholt.

Preisempfehlung: bis 6â‚¬ fÃ¼r alle Teile

author: {'steamid': '76561198047334829', 'num_games_owned': 8570, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1602518759}
review:
El Assassins de India.

[h1]Lo mejor:[/h1] 

- La historia transcurre en el aÃ±o 1841. Nuestro protagonista es un Asesino llamado Arbaaz Mir que deberÃ¡ recuperar el diamante Koh-i-Noor que no es mÃ¡s ni menos que un fragmento del EdÃ©n que pertenecÃ­a a la Hermandad de Asesinos y los templarios se la apoderaron despuÃ©s de llegar a India. TambiÃ©n deberÃ¡ proteger a su mentor y a su amante, una princesa.
- Comparado con el Assassins de China Ã©ste tiene escenarios mÃ¡s coloridos y mÃ¡s variados, hasta podemos visitar un templo de los miembros de la primera civilizaciÃ³n que estÃ¡ lleno de trampas! Este juego es mÃ¡s difÃ­cil que el Assassins de China y nos presenta mÃ¡s objetivos y situaciones que debemos atravesar y que no se repiten como en el de China donde por ejemplo tenÃ­amos que huir del fuego mÃ¡s de una vez o asesinar a distintos jefes de los tigres.  

Algunas situaciones que presenta este juego son:

Â Â Â Â Capturar a un agente enemigo utilizando medios no letales antes de que este se vaya.
Â Â Â Â Conseguir un disfraz y luego mezclarse con los NPCs civiles para poder pasar.
Â Â Â Â Escapar de los elefantes que nos persiguen y que estÃ¡n arrasando todo a su paso.
Â Â Â Â Usar un fusil de francotirador y apuntar con la mira para encargarnos de los guardias.

y muchas situaciones mÃ¡s.

- El juego sigue premiando el sigilo por encima de todo. Si no matamos ni incapacitamos a nadie y siempre permanecemos ocultos nos darÃ¡n bastantes puntos al finalizar la misiÃ³n. Si superamos una determinada cantidad de puntos obtendremos ciertas mejoras para nuestro protagonista.

- Se agregan las salas de desafÃ­o que son una serie de escenarios extraÃ±os dentro del Animus. AllÃ­ tenemos tres opciones:

Â Â Â Â Recoger: Tenemos que recoger todos los fragmentos de Animus en el menor tiempo posible y salir por una puerta.
Â Â Â Â Contratos: Debemos encontrar al objetivo con la vista de Ã¡guila, eliminarlo y salir por una puerta.
Â Â Â Â Asesinatos: Tenemos que matar a todos los enemigos y salir por una puerta.

Todos los escenarios llevan marcas de tiempo que podemos superar.

- Se agregan mÃ¡s habilidades Helix. Aparte del poder cambiar de escondrijo sin que nos vean como sucedÃ­a en el Assassins de China tambiÃ©n tenemos las siguientes habilidades:

Â Â Â Â La hoja Helix que nos permite hacer desaparecer a un enemigo como si no hubiera existido.
Â Â Â Â El camuflaje Helix que nos permite desaparecer al instante mientras tengamos Helix, hay que tener en cuenta que debemos permanecer quietos. 
Â Â Â Â El golpe Helix que nos permite arrasar con los enemigos que se nos vengan al instante.

- Arbaaz puede forzar cerraduras, distraer al enemigo con un silbido donde podemos moderar la intensidad, utilizar bombas sonoras para que el enemigo mire para otro lado, usar el dardo de cuerda para aferrarnos a ciertos techos y hasta puede usar un chackram sobre ciertas superficies para llegar a sitios difÃ­ciles de alcanzar y por ejemplo romper alguna soga, incluso avanzando en el juego tenemos una habilidad que nos permite matar a un enemigo con el chackram si le apuntamos a la cabeza. Pero lo mejor de todo es que ahora nuestro prota puede usar bombas de humo! Cuando la tiremos los guardias no van a poder ver nada hasta que el humo se disipe.
- El sistema de combate es el mismo que el Assassins de China pero mejor aplicado, ahora podemos bloquear directamente con una Ãºnica tecla y luego presionar la barra si queremos hacer una voltereta para pasar por encima del enemigo. Sin embargo, nuestro personaje sigue siendo muy dÃ©bil y lo mejor de todo es evitar las peleas directas, aunque habrÃ¡ un momento en que tengamos que pelear sÃ­ o sÃ­.
- Se puede realizar un asesinato mÃºltiple si estamos cerca de dos guardias parados o si estÃ¡n caminando uno al lado del otro.
- Hay enemigos muy molestos como algunos que no podemos matarlos de forma sigilosa a no ser que primero lo aturdamos con una bomba de humo, otros donde nuestros ataques normales no servirÃ¡n para nada e incluso hay un tipo de guardia que permanece escondido y la Ãºnica forma de matarlo tambiÃ©n es tirÃ¡ndole primero una bomba de humo. Y como si fuera poco algunos enemigos pueden entrar y salir de las puertas de refuerzos durante las patrullas. 
- Por el escenario puede haber guardias dormidos que se despertarÃ¡n si escuchan algo, claro que nos podemos encargar de ellos si queremos.
- Ahora es posible robarle a un guardia para obtener objetos de misiÃ³n o municiones sin necesidad de noquearlo o matarlo. Si lo matamos saquearemos su cuerpo. Hay que tener en cuenta que sÃ³lo se puede hacer esto con algunos enemigos.
- Ahora la vista de Ã¡guila aparte de resaltar alarmas, guardias y escondites tambiÃ©n nos dice que objetos tienen los enemigos para robarles y nos permite ver enemigos ocultos.
- Se puede rejugar en dificultad Plus y Plus difÃ­cil.
- Tenemos las trampas ruidosas que incluyen tigres en jaulas, algunos suelos que hacen ruido si corremos o caemos sobre ellos y cables trampa que si los tocamos pueden alertar a los guardias o provocar una explosiÃ³n. Lo bueno es que los cables trampa se pueden desarmar o tirarle con un chackram para que se activen y no volemos nosotros.

[h1]Lo peor:[/h1]

- Hay un bug muy grave en el recuerdo 5 del juego. En una parte luego de atravesar una serie de columnas movedizas nuestro personaje debe deslizarse sobre un tÃºnel y no lo hace. En vez de entrar al tÃºnel el personaje al deslizarse se queda trabado en la entrada del tÃºnel. La Ãºnica soluciÃ³n que encontrÃ© fue que en vez ir a "continuar partida" hay que ir a "cargar recuerdo -> secuencia de recuerdos 5". Haciendo eso volvemos a atravesar las columnas movedizas y ya funciona el deslizamiento.
- Mato a un guardia que estÃ¡ mirando por la ventana y medio cuerpo queda atravesando la pared. Clipping! :O
- En una parte nos piden que nos disfracemos como un guardia, para eso tenemos que encontrar tres objetos: botas, abrigo y un sombrero. Pero para que nos hacen buscar estas cosas por separado, porque no directamente tomar la ropa de un Ãºnico guardia????? es cuestiÃ³n de lÃ³gica... esto es un problema de diseÃ±o.
- Agarro el fusil de francotirador por primera vez y entro en el modo mira, pero no puedo disparar ni acercar ni alejar el zoom. Otro bug, el personaje se coloca el rifle pero no va a la mira automÃ¡tica. SÃ³lo al reiniciar el punto de control se fueron estos bugs.
- Esta bien, tenemos los extras como diseÃ±os conceptuales de enemigos, villanos, hÃ©roes o algÃºn atuendo, pero otra vez nos piden puntos UPlay.
- Cuando tenemos que combatir contra Burnes Ã©ste nos dice que serÃ¡ un combate justo. DespuÃ©s nos empieza a disparar y a tirar una bomba de humo para desaparecer y reaparecer en otra parte. Â¿Porque nosotros no podemos usar tambiÃ©n una bomba de humo o las habilidades Helix? Si Ã©l juega sucio porque yo no puedo jugar sucio? Otro problema de diseÃ±o.
- Los escenarios de las salas de desafÃ­o son muy pocos.
- Las mejoras como el aumento de municiÃ³n de chackram o aumento de salud que el juego nos asigna a nuestro protagonista siempre son automÃ¡ticas. No podemos elegir que mejorarle.
- El final del juego es muy abrupto, un poco decepcionante.
- Las habilidades Helix le restan realismo al juego.

La historia mejora bastante con respecto al Chronicles China, aunque sigue sin ser muy trascendente, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de todo eso no es mal juego, pero resulta agonizante el primer punto mencionado, asÃ­ que desgraciadamente no lo puedo recomendar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116113043', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1598995390}
review:
Nach dem Ã¼berraschend guten VorgÃ¤ngen habe ich mir von diesem nÃ¤chsten Teil der Chronicles Reihe Einiges erhofft. Sagen wir mal so: Meine Erwartungen wurden nicht enttÃ¤uscht, aber auch nicht wirklich Ã¼bertroffen.
"Assassin's Creed Chronicles: India" ist bei Weitem kein schlechtes Spiel. Ich hatte durchaus meinen SpaÃŸ damit, wieder durch die wunderschÃ¶n gestalteten Level zu hÃ¼pfen und zu klettern. Auch die neuen Gadgets fÃ¼r Arbaaz machen SpaÃŸ und lassen einen noch einmal umdenken im Gegensatz zum VorgÃ¤nger.StÃ¤rker als gedacht fÃ¤llt mir allerdings auf, dass diese drei Spiele eigentlich ein Spiel mit drei Episoden sein sollten. Grafisch hat sich nicht wirklich viel verÃ¤ndert, geschweige denn beim Spielprinzip. Nichts schlechtes, aber ich finde eine Aufteilung auf drei Spiele einfach unnÃ¶tig. Das aber nur nebenbei.Die Story ist im Gegensatz zum VorgÃ¤nger weniger spektakulÃ¤r. Gut, "China" hat auch nicht geglÃ¤nzt mit seiner simplen Rachestory, aber "India" plÃ¤tschert leider nur vor sich hin. Zuerst macht Arbaaz mit der Prinzessin rum, dann sucht er seinen Meister und man jagt erneut dem KÃ¤stchen aus dem VorgÃ¤nger hinterher. Wir erfahren dabei leider nichts Neues Ã¼ber das KÃ¤stchen, lediglich etwas Ã¼ber einen Diamanten, der etwas damit zu tun haben soll.
Noch kurz eine Sache zu den Leveln, in denen man schnell sein muss. Die waren mir hier etwas zu viel und zu "unfair". HÃ¤ufig reichte ein Fehler (den man auf jeden Fall zu Beginn macht) um zu scheitern, manchmal hatte ich aber auch das GefÃ¼hl, dass ich dem Elefanten oder der Explosion nur durch schieres GlÃ¼ck entkommen bin. Etwas frustrierend.
Jetzt aber noch was positives: Das Spiel ist einfach wunderschÃ¶n. Der Hintergrund haut einen um, die kleinen Details im Level selbst und vor allem das hÃ¤ufige "Ich kletter um eine Ecke und der ganze Bildschirm dreht sich" war ziemlich cool.
Alles in allem ein gutes Spiel, das einen kleinen Ticken schwÃ¤cher als der VorgÃ¤nger ist, aber immer noch verdammt gut. Kauft es euch aber wirklich am besten im Bundle mit den beiden anderen, andernfalls fehlt euch nicht nur ein groÃŸer Teil der Story sondern auch einige Erfahrung im Spielprinzip der Chronicles-Reihe, und die braucht ihr.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196023743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1599267996}
review:
The command's reaction is ridiculously slow, jeopardizing stealth moments when you need them the most.
I played the China chapter from this Chronicles series and don't remember having this issue.
Also, this one is more repetitive than normal, so I don't really feel challenged, with exception for the command issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114194598', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1586509564}
review:
This gameâ€™s controls are atrocious. The default control layout apparently expects you to have three arms. A decent custom one is hard to figure out since the game doesnâ€™t allow you to rebind like half of your keyboard or any additional mouse buttons to begin with. And even then, the combination of actions assigned to each key still make no sense. It took me slightly less than an hour to figure out some decent controls, but the game still only was barely playable afterwards. 

Besides all of that mess, the game is far from anything extraordinary. The background art and the music are nice, but the gameplay is nothing exciting and the story only varies in different tastes of cheesiness. Itâ€™s also rather short, somewhere between five and ten hours depending on the player.

So, in conclusion, you should only pick this game up if you buy it on sale, plan on playing it with a controller and really need to play every single game of the Assassinâ€™s Creed franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198850805838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1592417377}
review: this is lazy improvement from Assassin's Creed China. The "feel" is off, time pressure is too much and unnecessary. Today i got stuck on a level because I am short of ONE chakram, this is a simple task for the developers and testers to spot. I need to restart the whole chapter. Such lazy design. I got this on a sale, and still regret getting it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064600175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1592013713}
review:
It's bad. The game requires you to have lightning fast reflexes, gives you worst control fluidity than my grandfather's arthritic thumbs. Ask the character to jump and he crouches, ask him to climb the wall and he jumps into the abyss.
Also more than once the game bugs and doesn't let me proceed in the history without me restarting the game (i.e. climbable wall that won't let me grip it to climb). The story is horrid and makes no sense. All in all worst chronicles AC made, makes me wonder why they even bothered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071160105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1589740400}
review:
Nota: 3/5

De fato tenho gostado bastante da saga Chronicles, mas infelizmente o capÃ­tulo India fica um ponto abaixo do China. Como continuaÃ§Ã£o e como jÃ¡ Ã© praxe nas trilogias da Ubisoft - principalmente Assassin's Creed - o jogo segue o mesmo padrÃ£o e as mesmas mecÃ¢nicas de seu predecessor, contudo com algumas modificaÃ§Ãµes, atualizaÃ§Ãµes. Todavia, no caso do India, as novas mecÃ¢nicas ou nada de interessante acrescentaram ou mesmo pioraram o gameplay. Algumas das fases em que vocÃª tem que correr - das mais divertidas no capÃ­tulo China - aqui acabam nÃ£o entretendo tanto. As missÃµes de perseguiÃ§Ã£o sÃ£o enfadonhas e alguns detalhes, como as armadilhas, nÃ£o acrescentam em nada para a dificuldade, mas criam um elemento de frustraÃ§Ã£o completamente desnecessÃ¡rio.

Isso dito, ainda Ã© um jogo divertido. Aqui temos quase que uma versÃ£o indiana do Ezio, do ponto de vista do temperamento. Pelo menos, Ã© um personagem mais interessante que a Shao Jhun, do capÃ­tulo anterior. A histÃ³ria mantÃ©m sua simplicidade, mas traz elementos intrigantes, que advÃ©m desde o jogo anterior e do curta-metragem que Ã© seu prelÃºdio. Apesar dos percalÃ§os, a jogabilidade se mantÃ©m divertida. Os grÃ¡ficos sÃ£o bem mais coloridos que os do capÃ­tulo China e tentam trazer um toque Ã©tnico-cultural do ponto de vista artÃ­stico, o que Ã© um ponto positivo do jogo.

Mantenho minha recomendaÃ§Ã£o, principalmente para quem Ã© fÃ£ da franquia e estÃ¡ cansado dos jogos clÃ¡ssicos. Como um spin-off curto, Ã© boa diversÃ£o despretensiosa.

review:
Sigue teniendo segmentos donde necesitas ser pixel perfect para avanzar, pero mucho menos que en China, el juego se ve hermoso y se juega muy bien, mas si usas todo tu arsenal para hacerte la vida mas facil, aunque hubiera sido bueno tener mas municion en todo.
Eso si, en la mision donde tenes que noquear a un guardia, tenes que mantener apretado X meintras corres hacia el, es algo que jamas te dicen y puede que falle, por lejos la peor mision del juego.
